articles.quiztitle: Quiz for Linear Predictive Analysis of Speech

articles.q: In which domain the LP analysis plots the residual signal
articles.description: The amplitude of residual signal is plotted against time.

articles.q: At what rate speech is sampled in normal conditions?
articles.description: Speech is sampled at 8000 samples/second with 8 bits used to represent each sample.

articles.q: LPC reduces the sampling rate at what extent?
articles.description: linear predictive coding is a lossy form of compression. And it reduces the original signal to 2400 bits/sec with the reduction in sound quality

articles.q: What's the range of frequency of human speech?
articles.description: The frequency of human speech production ranges from around 300 Hz to 3400 Hz.

articles.q: What are the two features of sounds considered by the LPC Analysis while encoding and decoding the sound?
articles.description: The sounds can be characterzed by Glottal Pulse which is produced by either vibration of vocal cord; voiced or simply opening of vocal cord unvoiced.

articles.q: In what type of sound there is no Glottal pulses?
articles.description: Pitch is an unimportant attribute of unvoiced speech since there is no vibration of the vocal cords and no glottal pulses.

articles.q: In Source-Filter model what is the filter in sound production?
articles.description: The idea of the air from the lungs as a source and the vocal tract as a filter is called the source-filter model for sound production.

articles.q: During the production of unvoiced sound the characteristic of air through vocal tract is?
articles.description: During production the air can be periodic, when producing voiced sounds through vibrating vocal cords, or it can be turbulent and random when producing unvoiced sounds.

articles.q: What are the two key components of LPC model?
articles.description: Linear predictive coding model has two key components: analysis or encoding and synthesis or decoding.

articles.q: Which sound type has a high energy level and high amplitudes?
articles.description: Voiced sounds are usually vowels and can be considered as a pulse that is similar to periodic waveforms. These sounds have high average energy levels which means that they have very large amplitudes.

articles.q: For which sound type the LPC cannot give estimations?
articles.description: One misinterpretation by the LPC model is with a group of sounds known as nasal sounds. During the production of these sounds the nose cavity destroys the concept of a linear tube since the tube now has a branch.

articles.q: The time required for one wave cycle to completely pass a fixed position in voiced speech is called?
articles.description: The pitch period is the period of the vocal cord vibration that occurs during the production of voiced speech.

articles.q: The LP coefficients are estimated by which method?
articles.description: There are two approaches that can be used for the estimation of LP coefficients: autocorrelation and autocovariance.

articles.q: For the analysis of voiced sound what is the order of filter?
articles.description: If the segment contains voiced speech than a 10th order filter is used. This means that 11 values are needed: 10 reflection coefficients and the gain. If the segment contains unvoiced speech than a 4th order filter is used. This means that 5 values are needed: 4 reflection coefficients and the gain.

articles.q: What is the length of the window segment used to analyse speech?
articles.description: The segmental analysis corresponds to the processing of speech as short 10-30 ms overlapped 5-15 ms windows.

articles.q: The LP residual is obtained by
option: Low-pass filtering of speech using LP coefficients
High-pass filtering of speech using LP coefficients
articles.description: The error signal obtained by inverse filtering the speech signal is referred to as the LP residual.

articles.q: Linear predictive coding system models the vocal cord as what kind of linear filter?
articles.description: The linear predictive coding system models the vocal tract as an all pole linear filter. The excitation to this filter is either a pulse at the pitch frequency or random white noise depending on whether the speech segment is voiced or unvoiced.

articles.q: Which of the following LPC uses code book?
articles.description: Code Excited LPC uses code books

articles.q: How many past samples are used by linear predictive coders to estimate present sample?
articles.description: LPC uses weighted sum of past p smaples to estimate the current sample. This number varies from 10-15.

articles.q: Which sound can be characterized as white noise
articles.description: Unvoiced sounds are random noise where the Glottal pulse is absent.

articles.q: What are formants?
articles.description: The vocal tract can be considered as a cascade of resonator cavities with different shapes and sizes. The resonant frequencies of these cavities are referred to as formants.

articles.q: Which is the linear time varying filter in LP model?
articles.description: It is assumed that speech is produced by exciting a linear time-varying filter - the vocal tract by random noise for unvoiced speech segments, or a train of pulses for voiced speech.

articles.q: Glottal pulses are created by which mechanism?
option: Periodic opening and closing of vocal folds
articles.answer: Periodic opening and closing of vocal tract
articles.description: Glottal pulses created by periodic opening and closing of the vocal folds ;voiced speech

articles.q: How the formant locations are estimated by LP analysis
articles.description: The formant locations are estimated from LP Spectrum

articles.q: What is the nature of the normalized error curve
articles.description: The normalized error curve monotonically decreases.
